title: The Block 2019 episode 50 recap: Mark and Mitch go broke
text:
Nobody wants to watch anyone renovate a garage, so it’s lucky that this week the teams are also doing their roof terraces and redoing their disaster rooms.

But first they get to check out the other teams’ hallways, stairwells, study/media rooms and powder rooms in their various forms of incompleteness.

RELATED:

Episode 49 recap: Block room ‘looks like a public toilet’

Failed St Kilda auction a warning sign for The Block

They’re all fairly complimentary about one another, except for when they get to Mitch and Mark’s controversial winning spaces.

Jesse and Mel call their powder room “cheap and suburban” and their bedroom “the room you put your friends in that you don’t like”. Everyone agreed with the judges in their criticism of the “crime scene” tiling at the bottom of the stairs, and Jesse and Mel take the piss out of the under-the-stairs wine cellar.

Tess, meanwhile, can’t work out why Mark and Mitch’s bedroom styling was described as suitable for Kate Moss.

“Are her shoes filthy Grey Street hooker shoes?” she asks. Not nice, Tess.

And absolutely everyone agrees Jesse and Mel should have won, most of all, Jesse and Mel.

As the teams decide on which of their rooms to redo, Keith and Dan are out and about with those blue stickers, noting defects for the teams to fix. They find 50 on Mark and Mitch’s ground floor alone. It’s stressful just looking at them.

Tess and Luke have decided to redo their kitchen and dining room. They’re removing that fixed dining table jutting off the island bench, and are turning their formal lounge into a dining room instead, with a 250kg concrete table.

Matt and El’ise are also redoing their kitchen. After being disgusted with the judges’ criticism of her layout, she’s now come around to their way of thinking and after having lived with the kitchen agrees there’s nowhere near enough benchspace.

They’re getting rid of the obtrusive rangehood that sits like a monolith from 2001 A Space Odyssey in the middle of the kitchen and dining room, and moving the oven and coffee machine to free up some benchspace.

Elsewhere, Deb has reported her Block car stolen. She’s barefoot — can we pause for a moment and ask ourselves who goes shopping without shoes? — and wandering around Port Melbourne looking for it. When the local cops take time out of their busy schedules to investigate, promptly finding it around the corner, she sticks to her story that a thief took it, only to move it around the corner, citing as evidence the fact the driver’s seat was pushed way back.

The footage shows the seat was pushed back by Deb, who parked it around the corner and not where she swore blind she parked it.

“I have Block brain,” she says. Either that or concussion.

But really, the big news on this episode isn’t an unstolen car, it’s the fact that Block budgeting goodie-two shoes Mark and Mitch have run out of money. And not only run out, are in the red.

They get two big bills that are much higher than expected, and Mitch is soon muttering about Mark not being a good negotiator. It begins to dawn on the pair that they might be the only team on The Block paying full whack to their tradies. That added to fact they’ve employed a cast of thousands on their jobs means they have to send them all home.

“We’ve always been happy to pay the going rate… but these couple of bills came in big so we can’t have working because we can’t pay you,” Mark tells them.

Asked what the other teams will make of the development and Mark is spot on.

“I think people will be surprised, shocked, and excited and happy.”

Cue footage of the other contestants laughing uproariously.

“They’ve definitely isolated themselves in the last month. Do we not help them or do we show that we’re good people and help them,” El’ise muses.

It’s pretty clear what Luke and Tess’ attitude will be.

“We’re going to celebrate tonight because we are no longer the poor ones,” he says.
